data: Halaesa honours Gaius Vergilius Balbus, proquaestor
The stone was only seen by Muratori, and he did not provide a description

Assumed to be from Halaesa (Muratori notes that this is one of two which his own notes record at Nafplió in Greece (!), but both of which should rather be attributed to Sicily, and concludes that this should come from Halaesa).
Inscriptiones Graecae Siciliae et Italiae, additis graecis Galliae Hispaniae, Britanniae, Germaniae inscriptionibus

G. Kaibel, Inscriptiones Graecae Siciliae et Italiae, Additis Graecis Galliae Hispaniae, Britanniae, Germaniae Inscriptionibus, Inscriptiones Graecae Consilio et Auctoritate Academiae Litterarum Regiae Borussicae Editae. Volumen XIV., XIV (Berlin: Georgius Reimerus, 1890)
Novus thesaurus veterum inscriptionum in praecipuis earumdem collectionibus hactenus praetermissarum, collectore Ludovico Antonio Muratorio .... Tomus secundus

Ludovico Antonio Muratori, Novus Thesaurus Veterum Inscriptionum in Praecipuis Earumdem Collectionibus Hactenus Praetermissarum, Collectore Ludovico Antonio Muratorio .... Tomus Secundus, vol. 2 (Mediolani: ex aedibus Palatinis, 1740), http://arachne.uni-koeln.de/books/Muratori1740Vol2
Storia di Alesa, antica città di Sicilia

Gabriele Lancillotto Castelli principe di Torremuzza, Storia Di Alesa, Antica Città Di Sicilia (Palermo: Stamperia de SS. Appostoli in Piazza Vigliena, presso Pietro Bentivenga, 1753), http://arachne.uni-koeln.de/books/Castelli1763
Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio

Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio prolegomenis et notis illustrata, et iterum cum emendationibus, & auctariis evulgata

Gabriello Lancellotto Castelli Principe di Torremuzza, Siciliae et Objacentium Insularum Veterum Inscriptionum Nova Collectio Prolegomenis et Notis Illustrata, et Iterum Cum Emendationibus, & Auctariis Evulgata, 2nd (1st is 1769) (Palermo: typis regiis, 1784), http://arachne.uni-koeln.de/books/Castelli1784
A. Boeckh et al., Corpus Inscriptionum Graecarum, 4 vols (Berlin: Ex Officina Academica, 1828)
F. Bechtel et al., Sammlung Der Griechischen Dialekt-Inschriften, 4 vols (Göttingen: Vandenhoeck and Ruprecht, 1884)
Inscriptiones Graecae ad res Romanas pertinentes
R. Cagnat, J. Toutain, and P. Jouguet, Inscriptiones Graecae Ad Res Romanas Pertinentes, 4 vols (Paris: Ernest Leroux, 1906)
The silence of Norbanus. A note on provincial Quaestors under the Republic
E. Badian, ‘The Silence of Norbanus. A Note on Provincial Quaestors under the Republic’, American Journal of Philology 104 (1983): 156-171
Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia
Giacomo Manganaro, «Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia», Epigraphica 51 (1989): 161–96
Alesa Arconidea: ricerche su un'antica città della Sicilia tirrenica
A. Facella, Alesa Arconidea: Ricerche Su Un’antica Città Della Sicilia Tirrenica (Pisa: Edizioni della Normale, 2006)
Auxilia and gymnasia: a Sicilian model of Roman Republican Imperialism
J.R.W. Prag, ‘Auxilia and Gymnasia: A Sicilian Model of Roman Republican Imperialism’, Journal of Roman Studies 97 (2007): 68–100
Spazio pubblico e memoria civica. Le epigrafi dall'agora di Alesa
A. M. Prestianni Giallombardo, ‘Spazio Pubblico e Memoria Civica. Le Epigrafi Dall’agora Di Alesa’, in Agora Greca e Agorai Di Sicilia, ed. C. Ampolo (Pisa: Edizioni della Normale, 2012), 171–200

J.R.W. Prag and G. Tigano, Alesa Archonidea: Il Lapidarium, Introduzione All’archeologia Di Halaesa 8 (Palermo: Regione Siciliana, Assessorato beni culturali e identità siciliana, Dipartimento beni culturali e identità siciliana, 2017)

The people of the Halaesini (honour) Gaius Vergilius Balbus, son of Gaius, proquaestor, on account of his good will
Il popolo degli alesini (onora)  Gaio Vergilio Balbo, figlio di Gaio, proquestore, per la sua buona volontà

Editors from Franz in CIG onwards have assumed that the definite article must have dropped out in line 2 (whether omitted by accident in the transcription or already invisible on the stone) and restored it, as here. The text has the usual form of a compressed dedicatory honorific typical at Halaesa and ubiquitous in the Hellenistic world. It is however unusual, in comparison to the other Halaesan and Sicilian examples in two respects: firstly, the order of honorand and dedicant is reversed, with the city coming second, the Roman magistrate being named first; and secondly, it omits the reference to the deity in the dative to which the likely statue of the honorand is dedicated (typically, at Halaesa, ‘to all the gods’, although this is not always present; compare , , , also ). Both these differences are well attested in wider practice (see e.g. J. Ma, Statutes and Cities (Oxford 2013), 25), although they may be indicative of the fact that the honorand is the powerful figure of a Roman magistrate and that the text is a relatively late one (at Halaesa, compare the two lost Latin honorifics: that honouring Scipio (), which is second century BC, and uses the accusative for the honorand, in typical Greek form, but where the honorand comes second; and that for Augustus (), where the honorand is in dative, in typical Latin practice, but comes first, as here).

was praetor in 62 BC and praetorian governor of Sicily from 61-58 BC. His quaestorship will have been in the early 60s BC, at some point betwen 69 and 66 BC (Prag 2007: 307, Broughton MRR III (1986), 218). Honours for proquaestors, i.e. an individual whose term of office as quaestor had been extended by one or more years by the Senate, are rare, and usually seem to be for individuals who have in fact temporarily taken on the duties of a full praetorian governor (Badian 1983: 158).
ISic001178. Halaesa honours Gaius Vergilius Balbus, proquaestor

1Γάιον Οὐεργίλιον Γαίου υἱὸν Βάλβον
2ἀντιταμίαν <ὁ> δᾶμος τῶν Ἀλαισίνων
3εὐνοίας ἕνεκεν

1ΓΑΙΟΝΟΥΕΡΓΙΛΙΟΝΓΑΙΟΥΥΙΟΝΒΑΛΒΟΝ
2ΑΝΤΙΤΑΜΙΑΝΔΑΜΟΣΤΩΝΑΛΑΙΣΙΝΩΝ
3ΕΥΝΟΙΑΣΕΝΕΚΕΝ

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after CIG (Franz)

English translation

The people of the Halaesini (honour) Gaius Vergilius Balbus, son of Gaius, proquaestor, on account of his good will

Italian translation

Il popolo degli alesini (onora) Gaio Vergilio Balbo, figlio di Gaio, proquestore, per la sua buona volontà

commentary

Editors from Franz in CIG onwards have assumed that the definite article must have dropped out in line 2 (whether omitted by accident in the transcription or already invisible on the stone) and restored it, as here. The text has the usual form of a compressed dedicatory honorific typical at Halaesa and ubiquitous in the Hellenistic world. It is however unusual, in comparison to the other Halaesan and Sicilian examples in two respects: firstly, the order of honorand and dedicant is reversed, with the city coming second, the Roman magistrate being named first; and secondly, it omits the reference to the deity in the dative to which the likely statue of the honorand is dedicated (typically, at Halaesa, ‘to all the gods’, although this is not always present; compare ISic000770, ISic001177, ISic000612, also ISic001176). Both these differences are well attested in wider practice (see e.g. J. Ma, Statutes and Cities (Oxford 2013), 25), although they may be indicative of the fact that the honorand is the powerful figure of a Roman magistrate and that the text is a relatively late one (at Halaesa, compare the two lost Latin honorifics: that honouring Scipio (ISic000583), which is second century BC, and uses the accusative for the honorand, in typical Greek form, but where the honorand comes second; and that for Augustus (ISic000582), where the honorand is in dative, in typical Latin practice, but comes first, as here).

Gaius Vergilius Balbus was praetor in 62 BC and praetorian governor of Sicily from 61-58 BC. His quaestorship will have been in the early 60s BC, at some point betwen 69 and 66 BC (Prag 2007: 307, Broughton MRR III (1986), 218). Honours for proquaestors, i.e. an individual whose term of office as quaestor had been extended by one or more years by the Senate, are rare, and usually seem to be for individuals who have in fact temporarily taken on the duties of a full praetorian governor (Badian 1983: 158).
